data.title: Black Uber driver alleges racial profiling by Montreal police
data.meta_description: His positive attitude toward police changed dramatically last February after he says he was unlawfully arrested, handcuffed and ticketed.
data.text:
Article content

During the seven years that Jean Dieudonné Bernard has lived in Montreal, the 29-year-old Haitian man says he never had any run-ins with police.

In fact, Bernard said he would often be surprised when he would hear stories about police officers racially profiling visible minorities.

“I know this would not have happened if I was white,” Bernard said in an interview Monday.

Following the killing of George Floyd by a policeman in Minneapolis and demonstrations in Montreal to denounce the killings of black people, Bernard agreed to speak out about his own experience.

His story is emblematic of how an encounter with aggressive police officers can haunt victims indefinitely and blemish the reputation of the police force.

Bernard says he was waiting for two customers outside a busy club on Notre-Dame St. in Old Montreal when a police officer told him and another taxi driver to move along because there were too many cars outside the club.

After driving about 100 metres, Bernard noticed his Uber sticker had fallen off the rear window onto the back seat.

Before he could exit the vehicle to retrieve it, the two officers pulled up beside him and aggressively asked why he was still parked on the street, Bernard claims.

After replying that he was an Uber driver and that his customers would be arriving soon, Bernard said officers ordered him to park his vehicle in a private parking lot across the street.

When he objected, because his two customers had just turned up, Bernard says the officers became livid and told him he was being arrested for defying a police order.

After agreeing to pull into the parking lot, Bernard claims the officers, Constables David Bouffard and Jérôme Babin, pulled him out of his vehicle by his arms. Bernard says he was slammed violently against his car, handcuffed and placed in the police car, as his stunned clients and several observers looked on.

“They used extreme and unjustified force,” Bernard said in a complaint filed with Quebec’s police ethics commission, adding that his wrists and torso were sore.

“I repeatedly asked them why I was being arrested and they kept saying: ‘You will find out,’” he said. “I was sitting in the police car confused and worried.”

After searching his wallet, police went and spoke to Bernard’s two customers, he recalled.

When Bernard told the officers he was going to contest his unlawful arrest, one of them replied that his customers had agreed to testify against him in court. The two customers cancelled their ride and told Uber their driver had been arrested.

After hearing about the arrest, Uber blocked Bernard’s account for several days pending a review. He has since been reinstated.

Before releasing Bernard, the officers gave him tickets totalling $1,700 for ignoring a police order, parking at an angle and not having his Uber sticker in the window. Bernard, who is a part-time student, is contesting the tickets in court.

“It’s not normal that they would treat me this way,” Bernard said, adding that the encounter has left him feeling anxious and fearful of police officers.

Montreal police don’t comment on complaints filed with the police ethics commissioner, a spokesperson said on Monday.

Last fall, a report mandated by the city of Montreal showed that black and Indigenous people in Montreal were four times more likely to be subject to street checks by police than white people were. Arab people were two times more likely.

Montreal police chief Sylvain Caron acknowledged the presence of “systemic or organizational bias” within the force, but maintained that Montreal did not have “any racist police officers.”

Racial profiling incidents occur frequently in Montreal because of a lack of training and a lack of supervision of officers on the ground, said Fo Niemi, director of the Centre for Research-Action on Race Relations.

“There is a lack of leadership (on the force) and questions about the selection of candidates who join the SPVM,” Niemi said. “We see the same complaints year after year despite promises to change.”
